title: 104_hr2594
content: The Act may be cited as the "Railroad Unemployment Insurance Amendments Act of 1996". It includes a waiting period for unemployment benefits. The Railroad Unemployment Insurance Act is amended to specify the payment of unemployment benefits, including a waiting period for the first registration period. The Railroad Unemployment Insurance Act is amended to include a waiting period for unemployment benefits in cases of strikes. No benefits are payable for the first 14 days of unemployment due to a strike, with subsequent days being eligible for benefits as usual. If the strike continues after the initial period of unemployment ends, the waiting period may apply again. The Railroad Unemployment Insurance Act now includes a waiting period for benefits during strikes. If a period of unemployment due to a strike ends but the strike continues, a new waiting period may apply for the employee's first registration period in the new period of continuing unemployment. This period is defined as a single registration period or a series of consecutive or successive registration periods, each including more than 4 days of unemployment. The Railroad Unemployment Insurance Act includes a waiting period for benefits during strikes. A period of continuing unemployment ends when an employee exhausts rights to unemployment benefits. No benefits are payable if remuneration exceeds the base year monthly compensation base. The Railroad Unemployment Insurance Act has a waiting period for benefits during strikes. Benefits are not payable if an employee's remuneration exceeds the base year monthly compensation base. SEC. 3. WAITING PERIOD FOR SICKNESS BENEFITS. Amendment to the Railroad Unemployment Insurance Act regarding the payment of sickness benefits after the 4th consecutive day of sickness in a period of continuing sickness. Benefits are payable for each day of sickness in excess of 7 during the employee's first registration period in a period of continuing sickness. The employee's initial period of continuing sickness starts with 4 consecutive days of sickness and includes more than 4 days of sickness. A period of continuing sickness is defined as a consecutive or successive days of sickness, with no interruption of more than 90 days. The period ends when the employee exhausts sickness benefits. The period of continuing sickness ends when an employee exhausts sickness benefits. SEC. 4 amends the maximum daily benefit rate calculation under the Railroad Unemployment Insurance Act. SEC. 5 sets the maximum number of days for benefits. SEC. 5 amends the maximum number of days for benefits under the Railroad Unemployment Insurance Act to 130 days for both unemployment and sickness within a benefit year, with a limitation that benefits cannot exceed the employee's compensation in the base year. The maximum number of days for benefits under the Railroad Unemployment Insurance Act is 130 days for both unemployment and sickness within a benefit year, limited to not exceed the employee's compensation in the base year. Employees with 10 or more years of service may be eligible for extended benefits. Extended benefits may be paid for up to 65 days of unemployment or sickness within the benefit period, starting on the first day of unemployment. Extended benefits start on the first day of unemployment or sickness after exhausting normal benefits and last for 7 consecutive 14-day periods, ending when the employee qualifies for benefits again or reaches age 65. Extended benefits for sickness shall terminate when the employee turns 65, but may continue for paying benefits for days of unemployment. Employees with 10 or more years of service, who did not voluntarily retire or leave work without cause, and have 14 or more consecutive days of unemployment or sickness, may receive accelerated benefits. Extended benefits for sickness shall terminate when the employee turns 65, but may continue for paying benefits for days of unemployment. Employees with 10 or more years of service, who did not voluntarily retire or leave work without cause, and have 14 or more consecutive days of unemployment or sickness, may receive accelerated benefits. If an employee becomes a qualified employee for the next succeeding general benefit year after a period of unemployment or sickness, their succeeding benefit year shall begin on the first day of the month in which the unemployment or sickness started. The Railroad Unemployment Insurance Act provides extended sickness benefits until the employee turns 65. Accelerated benefits are available for employees with 10 or more years of service. Certain provisions, such as payment of supplemental unemployment benefits, are repealed. The amendments made by this Act will be effective on the date of enactment.
